clinical_study.official_title: Continuous Femoral Nerve Blockade and Single Shot Sciatic Nerve Block Compared to Intrathecal Morphine for Total Knee Arthroplasty

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

clinical_study.source: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Knee arthroplasty has a high potential for postoperative pain. This study compares analgesia and postoperative bleeding from intrathecal morphine with the continuous femoral and a single-shot sciatic nerve blockades.

detailed_description.textblock: This study aims to compare intrathecal morphine as a technique for analgesia with the femoral nerve blockade associated with a single-shot sciatic nerve blockade. Analgesic efficacy, the incidence of adverse effects, and postoperative bleeding were evaluated

primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline (zero hour: discharge of post-anesthesia care unit-PACU), 24hs, 48hs, 72 hours
primary_outcome.description: Pain with verbal numeric rating scale (VNRS). VNRS has 11 points, from zero to 10 (zero= no pain, 1-3 = mild pain, 4-5 = moderate pain, 7-9 = severe pain, 10 = unbearable pain).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline (discharge of post-anesthesia care unit-PACU), 24hs, 48hs, 72 hours

arm_group.description: femoral nerve blockade followed by a catheter placement for continuous infusion and a "single shot" block of the sciatic nerve

intervention.description: femoral nerve blockade followed by a catheter placement for continuous infusion and a "single shot" block of the sciatic nerve at the end of the surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged over 18 years old, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status from I to III who underwent total knee arthroplasty
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged below 18 years old, ASA IV or V physical status, infection near the puncture site, coagulation disorders, preexisting neurological disorders, allergy report to local anesthetics, pregnancy and lactation, contraindications to spinal block and refusal to sign an informed consent form
